pivotalTracks.title: Little Fly
pivotalTracks.analysis: This track is a stunning re-imagining of a William Blake poem set to music. The performance is a perfect example of the album's chamber jazz concept. Spalding's vocals are light and ethereal, and her bass playing is both supportive and contrapuntal. The intricate arrangement for the string trio weaves around the jazz trio, creating a sound that is both lush and intimate. It's a masterpiece of genre-blending and a showcase for Spalding's unique artistic vision.

albums.label: Blue Note
albums.lineup: Ambrose Akinmusire (trumpet), Walter Smith III (tenor saxophone), Gerald Clayton (piano), Harish Raghavan (bass), Justin Brown (drums)
albums.description: The major-label debut from trumpeter Ambrose Akinmusire, this album immediately established him as one of the most important and innovative voices of his generation. The music is a brilliant and emotionally deep extension of the post-bop tradition, characterized by Akinmusire's astonishing technical command, his unique, breathy tone, and his gift for writing complex, searching, and beautiful compositions. The album is a powerful statement from a young master.

pivotalTracks.title: The Walls of Lechuguilla
pivotalTracks.analysis: This track is a stunning showcase of Akinmusire's unique trumpet voice and the incredible dynamic range of his quintet. The piece moves from moments of sparse, quiet introspection to explosive, high-energy climaxes. Akinmusire's own solo is a tour de force, full of surprising interval leaps, long, flowing lines, and a masterful use of space. The track is a perfect example of the adventurous, emotionally charged, and technically brilliant sound that made Akinmusire a star.

albums.label: ACT
albums.lineup: Vijay Iyer (piano), Stephan Crump (bass), Marcus Gilmore (drums)
albums.description: A landmark album from one of the most acclaimed and innovative piano trios of the 21st century. 'Accelerando' is a powerful exploration of rhythm and groove, featuring brilliant re-imaginings of songs by artists as diverse as Michael Jackson, Duke Ellington, and the electronic duo Flying Lotus. The trio's incredible, near-telepathic interplay and their ability to deconstruct and rebuild complex rhythmic structures make this a thrilling and intellectually stimulating listen.

pivotalTracks.title: Human Nature
pivotalTracks.analysis: This brilliant deconstruction of the Michael Jackson hit is a perfect example of the Vijay Iyer Trio's genius. The trio transforms the pop ballad into a complex, rhythmically charged piece of modern jazz. They fragment the melody and subject it to intense rhythmic and harmonic variation, creating something that is both recognizable and completely new. The performance is a masterclass in modern trio interplay and creative reinterpretation.

albums.label: Motéma
albums.lineup: Gregory Porter (vocals), Chip Crawford (piano), Aaron James (bass), Emanuel Harrold (drums), Keyon Harrold (trumpet), Yosuke Sato (alto saxophone)
albums.description: The breakthrough second album from the artist who would become the most acclaimed male jazz vocalist of his generation. 'Be Good' showcases Gregory Porter's rich, warm baritone voice and his incredible gift for storytelling. The album is a beautiful blend of original compositions and standards, all delivered with a deep connection to the traditions of jazz, soul, blues, and gospel. The title track is a modern standard, a perfect example of his soulful and heartfelt style.

tracklist.title: The Way You Want to Live

pivotalTracks.title: Be Good (Lion's Song)
pivotalTracks.analysis: This beautiful, witty, and soulful original composition is the centerpiece of the album and a perfect showcase of Gregory Porter's immense talent. The song is a gentle, swinging waltz that tells a charming story of unrequited love. Porter's vocals are rich and expressive, and his phrasing is masterful. The track became an instant classic and established him as a major new voice in the tradition of great jazz singers.

albums.label: Blue Note
albums.lineup: Robert Glasper (piano, Fender Rhodes), Casey Benjamin (vocoder, saxophone), Derrick Hodge (bass), Chris Dave (drums), and numerous guest vocalists including Erykah Badu, Lalah Hathaway, and Mos Def.
albums.description: A groundbreaking, Grammy-winning album that completely redefined the conversation between jazz, hip-hop, and R&B for the 21st century. On 'Black Radio,' Robert Glasper and his Experiment band created a new, fluid musical language that seamlessly blended the harmonic sophistication of jazz with the grooves of neo-soul and the rhythms of hip-hop. Featuring a star-studded cast of guest vocalists, the album was a massive critical and commercial success that brought a new, young, and diverse audience to jazz.

pivotalTracks.title: Black Radio
pivotalTracks.analysis: The title track, featuring yasiin bey (Mos Def), is a powerful statement of the album's mission to break down genre barriers. The track is built on a foundation of Chris Dave's famously complex and 'drunk' drumming style, which perfectly captures a hip-hop feel. Over this, Glasper's Fender Rhodes provides a soulful, jazzy harmonic bed for bey's poetic and politically charged vocals. The track is a perfect synthesis of the three genres and a definitive anthem of this new movement in music.

albums.label: The Leaf Label
albums.lineup: Pete Wareham (tenor saxophone), Shabaka Hutchings (tenor saxophone), Kushal Gaya (vocals), Satin Singh (percussion), Tom Skinner (drums), Ruth Goller (bass)
albums.description: The explosive debut album from the London-based supergroup, 'Melt Yourself Down' is a ferocious and exhilarating fusion of high-energy punk jazz, North African rhythms, and funk. Led by saxophonist Pete Wareham and featuring the powerhouse tenor of Shabaka Hutchings, the band created a sound that is chaotic, danceable, and utterly unique. It's a raw, sweaty, and joyous blast of energy that was a key document in the revitalized UK jazz scene.

pivotalTracks.title: Fix My Life
pivotalTracks.analysis: The album's opening track is a perfect introduction to the band's blistering sound. It kicks off with a powerful, interlocking two-tenor saxophone riff that immediately establishes a sense of urgency. The track is driven by a frenetic, polyrhythmic beat and the wild, incantatory vocals of Kushal Gaya. It's a thrilling collision of genres that is both viscerally powerful and musically sophisticated, a definitive statement of the new 'punk jazz' sound.

albums.label: Mack Avenue
albums.lineup: Cécile McLorin Salvant (vocals), Aaron Diehl (piano), Rodney Whitaker (bass), Herlin Riley (drums), James Chirillo (guitar)
albums.description: The major-label debut that established Cécile McLorin Salvant as the most important and acclaimed jazz vocalist of her generation. 'WomanChild' is a stunning showcase of her incredible vocal command, her deep knowledge of jazz and blues history, and her unique ability to inhabit a song's narrative. The album features a mix of standards and obscure, early blues and jazz tunes, all delivered with a theatrical flair, emotional depth, and technical brilliance that was simply breathtaking. It earned her the first of many Grammy nominations.

tracklist.title: I Didn't Know What Time It Was
You Bring Out the Savage in Me

pivotalTracks.title: St. Louis Gal
pivotalTracks.analysis: This performance of a nearly-forgotten 1920s blues tune is a perfect example of Salvant's unique artistry. She attacks the song with a playful, theatrical, and slightly mischievous energy, showcasing her incredible control over dynamics, timbre, and phrasing. The performance is a masterclass in historical reinterpretation, breathing new life into the song and demonstrating her commitment to exploring the deep and often overlooked corners of the jazz and blues tradition.

albums.label: Brainfeeder
albums.lineup: Kamasi Washington (tenor saxophone), Thundercat (electric bass), Ronald Bruner Jr. (drums), Cameron Graves (piano), Ryan Porter (trombone), and a large ensemble including a choir and string orchestra.
albums.description: A monumental, three-hour-long triple album that revitalized spiritual jazz for a new generation. 'The Epic' is a sprawling, ambitious work that blends the cosmic explorations of John Coltrane and Pharoah Sanders with the sounds of funk, soul, and hip-hop. Featuring a massive orchestra and choir, the music is powerful, cinematic, and deeply spiritual. Its release on the influential electronic label Brainfeeder brought a new, young audience to jazz and made Kamasi Washington a global star.

pivotalTracks.title: The Rhythm Changes
pivotalTracks.analysis: A key track from the album, 'The Rhythm Changes' is a powerful fusion of spiritual jazz and modern funk. The track features a soaring, anthemic melody and a brilliant, searching tenor saxophone solo from Washington. The incredible vocal performance from Patrice Quinn and the lush string and choir arrangements give the piece a cinematic, epic quality. It's a perfect example of how Washington successfully updated the sound of 1970s spiritual jazz for the 21st century.

albums.label: International Anthem
albums.lineup: Makaya McCraven (drums), Matt Ulery (bass), Marquis Hill (trumpet), Junius Paul (bass), Justin Thomas (vibraphone), Jeff Parker (guitar), and others.
albums.description: A groundbreaking album that introduced drummer and producer Makaya McCraven's unique 'organic beat music' concept. 'In the Moment' was created by recording hours of live, improvised performances and then editing, looping, and post-producing the material in the studio. The result is a brilliant fusion of the spontaneity of live jazz with the aesthetics of modern hip-hop production. The album was a critical sensation and established McCraven as a major new innovator.

pivotalTracks.title: The Jaunt
pivotalTracks.analysis: This track is a perfect example of McCraven's innovative process. It features a simple, catchy vibraphone melody over a laid-back, swinging groove. The genius of the track lies in its construction: it feels like a perfectly crafted beat, but it's actually a carefully edited slice of a longer, freely improvised performance. The track's blend of organic improvisation and tight, beat-like structure made it a standout and a key document of the burgeoning 'nu jazz' scene.

albums.label: Impulse!
albums.lineup: Shabaka Hutchings (tenor saxophone), Theon Cross (tuba), Tom Skinner (drums), Eddie Hick (drums)
albums.description: A powerful and politically charged album from the Shabaka Hutchings-led supergroup. 'Your Queen Is a Reptile' is a celebration of influential black women throughout history, with each track dedicated to a different 'queen.' The music is a visceral, high-energy fusion of jazz, Caribbean rhythms, and London club culture, driven by the unique and powerful sound of two drummers and Theon Cross's thunderous tuba, which serves as the bass. The album was a critical sensation and a key document of the modern UK jazz scene.

tracklist.title: My Queen Is Mamie Phipps Clark
My Queen Is Anna Julia Cooper

pivotalTracks.title: My Queen Is Ada Eastman
pivotalTracks.analysis: The opening track, dedicated to Hutchings's great-grandmother, is a perfect introduction to the band's unique sound. The piece is built on a foundation of hypnotic, interlocking rhythms from the two drummers and a powerful, agile tuba line from Theon Cross. Over this, Hutchings's saxophone melody is both lyrical and fiery. The track is a joyous and defiant celebration, a danceable protest song that sets the political and musical tone for the entire album.

albums.albumTitle: Trust in the Lifeforce of the Deep Mystery
albums.label: Impulse!
albums.lineup: King Shabaka (Shabaka Hutchings) (tenor saxophone), Danalogue the Conqueror (Dan Leavers) (keyboards, synthesizers), Betamax Killer (Max Hallett) (drums)
albums.description: The second album from the London-based cosmic jazz trio, 'Trust in the Lifeforce of the Deep Mystery' is a powerful and cinematic journey. The music is a seamless fusion of spiritual jazz, psychedelic rock, and electronic music, creating a sound that is both futuristic and primal. Shabaka Hutchings's saxophone soars over a bed of pulsating synthesizer textures and powerful, driving drums, creating a sound that is both danceable and transportive. The album was shortlisted for the Mercury Prize.

tracklist.title: Because the End Is Really the Beginning

pivotalTracks.title: Summon the Fire
pivotalTracks.analysis: A high-energy anthem and a standout track, 'Summon the Fire' is the perfect distillation of the band's sound. The track is built on a driving, almost rock-like drum beat and a powerful, pulsating synthesizer riff. Over this, Shabaka Hutchings's saxophone plays a simple, infectious, and anthemic melody that builds in intensity. It's a joyous and cathartic blast of energy that became a live favorite and a perfect entry point to the band's cosmic sound world.

albums.albumTitle: We Are Sent Here by History
albums.label: Impulse!
albums.lineup: Shabaka Hutchings (tenor saxophone), Mthunzi Mvubu (alto saxophone), Siyabonga Mthembu (vocals), Ariel Zamonsky (bass), Gontse Makhene (percussion), Tumi Mogorosi (drums)
albums.description: A powerful and politically charged album conceived as a single, continuous sonic poem. Recorded in South Africa with a band of brilliant Johannesburg-based musicians, the album is a deep exploration of spiritual jazz and its connections to the African diaspora. The music is intense, meditative, and ritualistic, featuring fiery improvisations, powerful spoken-word vocals, and deep, churning polyrhythms. It's a profound statement on history, identity, and the end of the world as we know it.

tracklist.title: Go My Heart, Go to Heaven
The Coming of the Strange Ones

pivotalTracks.title: Go My Heart, Go to Heaven
pivotalTracks.analysis: This track is a perfect example of the album's spiritual and ritualistic quality. It features a beautiful, mournful horn melody that slowly builds in intensity over a foundation of hypnotic percussion and bass. Siyabonga Mthembu's vocals are both a lament and a call to action. The piece has a powerful, prayer-like quality that is a hallmark of the spiritual jazz tradition, connecting the political and the personal in a single, profound statement.

albums.label: Concord Jazz
albums.lineup: Nubya Garcia (tenor saxophone), Joe Armon-Jones (piano, keyboards), Daniel Casimir (bass), Sam Jones (drums)
albums.description: The highly anticipated debut album from one of the leading figures of the vibrant London jazz scene. 'Source' is a brilliant and expansive work that seamlessly blends straight-ahead jazz with the sounds of dub, reggae, cumbia, and soul. The music is both intellectually deep and eminently danceable, showcasing Garcia's powerful and lyrical tenor saxophone voice and her considerable talents as a composer. The album was a critical triumph and a definitive statement of the new, globally-influenced sound of UK jazz.

tracklist.title: Together Is a Beautiful Place to Be

pivotalTracks.title: Pace
pivotalTracks.analysis: The album's opening track is a powerful statement of intent. It begins with a slow, meditative intro before launching into a high-energy, up-tempo workout. The track showcases the incredible tightness and dynamic range of Garcia's quartet, particularly the brilliant, energetic drumming of Sam Jones. Garcia's own solo is a tour de force, full of long, flowing lines, a huge, warm tone, and a deep sense of rhythmic drive. It's a perfect introduction to her modern and multifaceted sound.

albums.artist: Floating Points, Pharoah Sanders & The London Symphony Orchestra
albums.label: Luaka Bop
albums.lineup: Pharoah Sanders (tenor saxophone, vocals), Sam Shepherd (Floating Points) (piano, synthesizers, electronics), The London Symphony Orchestra (strings)
albums.description: A critically acclaimed masterpiece, 'Promises' is a single, 46-minute piece of music composed by the electronic musician Floating Points. The work is built around a simple, seven-note musical phrase that repeats throughout, creating a hypnotic and meditative soundscape. Over this, the legendary spiritual jazz saxophonist Pharoah Sanders delivers a performance of incredible tenderness and vulnerability, his saxophone cries and whispers floating through the shimmering textures of the electronics and the lush strings of the London Symphony Orchestra. It's a breathtakingly beautiful and genre-defying work.

pivotalTracks.title: Promises (Movements 1-9)
pivotalTracks.analysis: The entire album is a single, continuous work that must be heard in its entirety. The central, repeating harpsichord-like motif acts as an anchor, creating a sense of constant, gentle motion. The most pivotal moments are the entrances of Pharoah Sanders's saxophone. His playing is remarkably restrained and soulful, a testament to a lifetime of musical wisdom. The way his saxophone interacts with the orchestra and the electronics is the heart of the piece, a sublime dialogue between three distinct musical worlds that results in a work of profound and unique beauty.

albums.label: Impulse!
albums.lineup: Shabaka Hutchings (tenor saxophone), Theon Cross (tuba), Edward Wakili-Hick (drums), Tom Skinner (drums), and guest artists.
albums.description: The fourth and final album from the groundbreaking UK jazz group, 'Black to the Future' is a powerful and poignant statement. Conceived as a sonic response to the Black Lives Matter protests of 2020, the album is a fiery, rhythm-driven exploration of Black identity and rage. Featuring guest appearances from poets and vocalists like Moor Mother and Angel Bat Dawid, the music is a visceral and politically charged blend of jazz, Afro-Caribbean rhythms, and grime, all driven by the band's signature tuba-and-two-drummers lineup.

pivotalTracks.title: Hustle
pivotalTracks.analysis: Featuring a guest vocal from Kojey Radical, 'Hustle' is a perfect example of the band's unique fusion of sounds. The track is built on a relentlessly energetic and complex polyrhythmic groove from the two drummers and tuba. Over this, Hutchings's saxophone and Radical's grime-influenced vocals trade fiery and politically charged lines. The track's blend of Caribbean soca rhythms, jazz improvisation, and UK rap makes it a powerful and definitive statement of the modern London sound.

albums.label: Blue Note
albums.lineup: Immanuel Wilkins (alto saxophone), Micah Thomas (piano), Daryl Johns (bass), Kweku Sumbry (drums)
albums.description: An ambitious and deeply spiritual album from the young alto saxophonist, 'The 7th Hand' is a seven-part suite that explores the relationship between music and divine presence. The music moves from moments of lyrical, hymn-like beauty to sections of intense, fiery collective improvisation. The album culminates in a nearly 30-minute-long free-form piece that showcases the incredible chemistry and adventurous spirit of Wilkins's quartet. It's a major artistic statement from one of the leading voices in contemporary jazz.

pivotalTracks.title: Emanation
pivotalTracks.analysis: The opening track of the suite immediately establishes the album's spiritual and compositional ambition. The piece is built on a beautiful, memorable melody that has the quality of a modern spiritual. Wilkins's alto saxophone sound is pure and searing, full of a deep, blues-inflected cry. The performance showcases the incredible tightness and dynamic range of his quartet, moving seamlessly from tender quietude to powerful climaxes. It's a perfect introduction to the album's profound and beautiful musical world.

albums.label: Nonesuch
albums.lineup: Cécile McLorin Salvant (vocals), Sullivan Fortner (piano, keyboards), and various other musicians.
albums.description: A stylistically vast and emotionally powerful album, 'Ghost Song' finds Cécile McLorin Salvant moving far beyond the conventions of a traditional jazz singer. The album is a brilliant and eclectic tapestry of sound, blending original compositions with radical reinterpretations of songs from genres as diverse as Kate Bush's art-pop, English folk, and 'The Wizard of Oz.' It's a deeply personal and theatrical exploration of love and loss, showcasing her unparalleled vocal talent and her unique genius as a curator and storyteller.

pivotalTracks.title: Ghost Song
pivotalTracks.analysis: The stunning title track is a perfect example of the album's genre-defying brilliance. The song begins with a haunting, almost folk-like a cappella vocal before being joined by a sparse, bluesy piano. It then erupts into a powerful, soulful groove, showcasing Salvant's incredible dynamic range. The song's unique structure and its blend of different musical traditions make it a powerful and original statement, a perfect encapsulation of the album's ambitious and deeply personal artistry.

albums.label: International Anthem
albums.lineup: Makaya McCraven (drums, production), Jeff Parker (guitar), Junius Paul (bass), Brandee Younger (harp), Greg Ward (saxophone), and others.
albums.description: The culmination of over seven years of work, 'In These Times' is Makaya McCraven's most ambitious and beautiful album. The record expands on his signature 'organic beat music' style, blending live-session recordings with post-production techniques, but this time incorporating lush, intricate orchestral arrangements. The music is a brilliant fusion of jazz, hip-hop, and classical music, creating a sound that is both epic and intimate. It's a masterpiece of modern production and a profound statement on history, community, and perseverance.

pivotalTracks.title: In These Times
pivotalTracks.analysis: The album's majestic title track is a perfect showcase of McCraven's expanded vision. The piece is built on a complex 7/4 time signature, but the groove is so hypnotic and organic that it feels completely natural. The track seamlessly blends Brandee Younger's beautiful harp playing, lush string arrangements, and fiery improvisations into a cohesive whole. It's a stunning piece of music that is both rhythmically complex and emotionally direct, a definitive statement from a modern master.

albums.label: Impulse!
albums.lineup: Shabaka Hutchings (shakuhachi, flutes, clarinet), and other collaborators.
albums.description: A surprising and beautiful departure from the fiery, high-energy music of his bands Sons of Kemet and The Comet Is Coming. 'Afrikan Culture' is a meditative and atmospheric EP that finds Shabaka Hutchings setting aside his tenor saxophone to focus on a variety of flutes, including the Japanese shakuhachi. The music is sparse, beautiful, and deeply spiritual, built on layers of woodwinds, percussion, and subtle electronic textures. It's a deeply personal and introspective work that reveals a new side of this visionary artist.

tracklist.title: Memories don't live like people do

pivotalTracks.title: Black meditation
pivotalTracks.analysis: The opening track immediately establishes the album's introspective mood. The piece is built on layers of Shabaka's own overdubbed flutes, creating a shimmering, hypnotic texture. There is no traditional rhythm section, just a floating soundscape that invites deep listening. It's a beautiful and courageous piece of music that showcases Shabaka's commitment to sonic and spiritual exploration, moving beyond the familiar to create a new and personal sound world.

albums.label: Apeshit / Blue Note
albums.lineup: DOMi Louna (keyboards), JD Beck (drums), and guest artists including Thundercat, Herbie Hancock, Snoop Dogg, and Anderson .Paak.
albums.description: The highly anticipated debut album from the internet-famous prodigy duo. 'NOT TiGHT' is a stunning display of instrumental virtuosity, blending the harmonic complexity of jazz fusion with the deep pocket of hip-hop and the quirky humor of internet culture. DOMi's lightning-fast keyboard runs and JD Beck's incredibly complex, off-kilter drumming create a sound that is dense, playful, and utterly unique. The album, featuring a star-studded list of guests, was a viral sensation and a definitive statement from a new generation of jazz musicians.

tracklist.title: U DON'T HAVE TO ROB ME

pivotalTracks.title: SMiLE
pivotalTracks.analysis: A standout track that perfectly captures the duo's unique sound. The piece is built on a complex, constantly shifting drum beat from JD Beck that combines the precision of a drum machine with the fluidity of a live player. Over this, DOMi's keyboards provide a bed of lush, sophisticated harmonies and a series of dazzlingly fast solos. The track's blend of insane technicality, deep groove, and a playful, almost cartoonish sensibility is a perfect encapsulation of their viral appeal and musical genius.

albums.label: Riverside
albums.lineup: Blue Mitchell (trumpet), Curtis Fuller (trombone), Jimmy Heath (tenor saxophone), Wynton Kelly (piano), Sam Jones (bass), Philly Joe Jones (drums)
albums.description: A classic, all-star hard bop session that finds trumpeter Blue Mitchell leading a top-tier lineup. The music is a perfect example of the sophisticated, swinging, and soulful jazz being recorded in the late 1950s. The arrangements by Jimmy Heath and Benny Golson are superb, and the solos from Mitchell, trombonist Curtis Fuller, and Heath are all brilliant. The presence of the powerhouse rhythm section of Wynton Kelly, Sam Jones, and Philly Joe Jones elevates the session to a must-have for any hard bop enthusiast.

pivotalTracks.title: Minor Vamp
pivotalTracks.analysis: A hard-driving, minor-key blues that perfectly showcases the energy and skill of this all-star sextet. The track is propelled by the explosive drumming of Philly Joe Jones and the impeccable swing of Wynton Kelly's piano. Blue Mitchell's trumpet solo is a model of bluesy, lyrical invention, and the solos from Curtis Fuller and Jimmy Heath are equally fiery and creative. It's a quintessential example of a classic Blue Note-style 'blowing session,' where top-tier musicians push each other to their best.

albums.label: Impulse!
albums.lineup: Yusef Lateef (tenor saxophone, flute, oboe), Georges Arvanitas (piano), Reggie Workman (bass), James Black (drums)
albums.description: A hypnotic and meditative journey from the great multi-instrumentalist Yusef Lateef. The album continues his pioneering exploration of 'world music' within a jazz context, featuring his use of flute and oboe to evoke Eastern tonalities. The music is deeply atmospheric and spiritual, using simple, repetitive vamps to create a trance-like state. It's a key document of Lateef's unique ability to create music that is both intellectually deep and spiritually resonant.

pivotalTracks.title: Psychicemotus
pivotalTracks.analysis: The hypnotic title track is a perfect example of Lateef's exploratory style. The piece is built on a simple, repeated bass line that creates a trance-like state. Over this, Lateef's flute playing is atmospheric and searching, using unusual scales and tonalities that reflect his deep interest in Eastern music. The track showcases his unique ability to create a meditative and spiritual mood, a key element of the burgeoning spiritual jazz movement.

albums.label: CTI
albums.lineup: Freddie Hubbard (trumpet), Joe Henderson (tenor saxophone), Herbie Hancock (electric piano), George Benson (guitar), Ron Carter (bass), Jack DeJohnette (drums), Richard 'Pistol' Allen (percussion), Weldon Irvine (tambourine)
albums.description: A brilliant transitional album from trumpeter Freddie Hubbard, 'Straight Life' captures a pivotal moment as fiery, acoustic post-bop began to fully embrace electric instrumentation. The session features an all-star lineup navigating long, open-ended improvisations over infectious vamps. It's a key document that bridges the gap between the acoustic 60s and the electric 70s, retaining the high-level improvisation of hard bop within a new, electric context.

pivotalTracks.title: Straight Life
pivotalTracks.analysis: The 17-minute title track is a marathon of open-ended improvisation, built on a simple, infectious vamp. Herbie Hancock's Fender Rhodes and George Benson's guitar add a new textural dimension, creating a funky, electric soundscape. Over this, Hubbard's trumpet solo is a stunning display of power, endurance, and brilliant ideas, making this a quintessential performance of early jazz fusion.

albums.label: Atlantic
albums.lineup: Billy Cobham (drums), Tommy Bolin (guitar), Jan Hammer (electric piano, synthesizer), Lee Sklar (electric bass), Joe Farrell (flute, saxophones), Jimmy Owens (trumpet), Ron Carter (acoustic bass)
albums.description: A landmark album that set a new standard for fusion drumming and became a cornerstone of the jazz-rock movement. 'Spectrum' is a high-energy showcase for Billy Cobham's incredible power and polyrhythmic complexity. The album is famous for its explosive interplay between Cobham's drums, the heavy rock guitar of a young Tommy Bolin, and Jan Hammer's futuristic synthesizer work. It's a visceral and virtuosic album that had a profound influence on both jazz and rock musicians.

tracklist.title: Searching for the Right Door / Spectrum
To the Women in My Life / Le Lis

pivotalTracks.title: Stratus
pivotalTracks.analysis: This track is a masterclass in funky, powerful, and complex drumming, but it's also an iconic piece of music that has been famously sampled by Massive Attack for their song 'Safe from Harm.' The interplay between Cobham's explosive polyrhythms, Tommy Bolin's heavy rock guitar, and Jan Hammer's futuristic synth work created a quintessential piece of high-energy jazz-rock that influenced countless musicians across multiple genres.

albums.label: Columbia
albums.lineup: Herbie Hancock (keyboards, synthesizer), Bennie Maupin (reeds, piccolo), Eddie Henderson (trumpet), Julian Priester (trombone), Buster Williams (bass), Billy Hart (drums), Patrick Gleeson (synthesizer)
albums.description: The final statement from Herbie Hancock's visionary Mwandishi band, 'Sextant' is a deep dive into avant-garde electronic space-jazz. The album is a challenging and atmospheric work, characterized by its use of synthesizers, exotic percussion, and collective improvisation. It's a key document of the adventurous and experimental spirit of early 70s electronic jazz, a cosmic and uncompromising work that stands in stark contrast to the funk-based fusion Hancock would explore later the same year.

pivotalTracks.title: Hornets
pivotalTracks.analysis: This sprawling, 19-minute track is a whirlwind of abstract textures, driven by a bubbling, nervous synthesizer rhythm and featuring collective improvisation from the horns. The music is challenging and sonically inventive, showcasing a much more experimental and less commercial side of fusion. It stands as a key document of the adventurous spirit of early 70s electronic jazz, with Patrick Gleeson's synthesizer work being particularly groundbreaking.

albums.label: Columbia
albums.lineup: Miles Davis (trumpet, organ), Dave Liebman (flute), Pete Cosey (guitar), Reggie Lucas (guitar), Michael Henderson (bass), Al Foster (drums), Mtume (percussion), and many others.
albums.description: A sprawling double album that collects recordings from a four-year period, 'Get Up With It' is one of Miles Davis's most diverse and challenging works of the 1970s. The album is most famous for the 32-minute elegy for Duke Ellington, 'He Loved Him Madly,' a cornerstone of ambient music. The record explores everything from dense funk to atmospheric soundscapes, serving as a final, powerful statement before Davis's temporary retirement from music.

pivotalTracks.title: He Loved Him Madly
pivotalTracks.analysis: This track is a landmark of ambient music. A sprawling, 32-minute elegy for the recently deceased Duke Ellington, the piece creates a dark, atmospheric, and mournful soundscape. Miles Davis's lonely organ chords and trumpet cries float over a hypnotic, static groove. The piece's focus on texture and mood over melody was revolutionary, profoundly influencing ambient and electronic artists like Brian Eno and cementing Davis's status as a perpetual innovator.

albums.label: CBS/Sony
albums.lineup: Miles Davis (trumpet, organ), Dave Liebman (soprano, tenor saxophone), Azar Lawrence (tenor saxophone), Pete Cosey (guitar), Reggie Lucas (guitar), Michael Henderson (bass), Al Foster (drums), Mtume (percussion)
albums.description: Recorded live at Carnegie Hall, 'Dark Magus' captures the raw, uncut, and ferocious energy of Miles Davis's final electric band. The music is a dense and often abrasive onslaught of sound, characterized by deep funk rhythms, dual-guitar attacks, and Miles's searing trumpet filtered through a wah-wah pedal. The revolutionary, distorted guitar work of Pete Cosey, in particular, pushed the music into uncharted territory, creating a sound that bordered on noise rock and was a precursor to many future experimental genres.

pivotalTracks.title: Moja
pivotalTracks.analysis: This 25-minute track is a relentless immersion into the dense, polyrhythmic funk of Miles's live band. The music is a continuous flow of energy, with no discernible theme or structure, just a deep, dark groove over which the soloists improvise with raw power. Pete Cosey's guitar playing is particularly noteworthy, a maelstrom of feedback and distortion that was unlike anything else in jazz at the time. The track is a powerful document of the band at its most uncompromising and intense.

albums.label: Epic
albums.lineup: Jaco Pastorius (fretless bass), Don Alias (congas), Herbie Hancock (keyboards), Lenny White (drums), Sam & Dave (vocals), Michael Brecker (tenor saxophone), Randy Brecker (trumpet), and others.
albums.description: This debut album single-handedly revolutionized the role of the electric bass in music. It's a stunning showcase of Jaco Pastorius's unparalleled virtuosity, his unique, singing fretless tone, and his sophisticated compositional and arranging skills. The album moves seamlessly between jaw-dropping bebop, deep funk grooves, and lush, orchestrated ballads, establishing Jaco as a major new force in music and the electric bass as a powerful solo instrument.

pivotalTracks.title: Donna Lee
pivotalTracks.analysis: The album's opening track was a declaration of independence for the electric bass. Jaco's stunning solo bass interpretation of a notoriously difficult Charlie Parker bebop standard, accompanied only by congas, was a feat of virtuosity that immediately announced a revolutionary new voice. His flawless execution of the complex melody, combined with his unique tone and rich harmonic substitutions, demonstrated that the bass could be a lead instrument of astonishing lyrical power.

albums.label: Columbia
albums.lineup: Joe Zawinul (keyboards), Wayne Shorter (saxophones), Alphonso Johnson (bass), Jaco Pastorius (fretless bass on two tracks), Chester Thompson (drums), Narada Michael Walden (drums)
albums.description: A pivotal album for Weather Report, 'Black Market' marked a shift toward a more groove-oriented and world music-influenced sound. The album is most notable for featuring the debut of bass prodigy Jaco Pastorius on two tracks, pointing the way toward the band's future commercial peak. The music is a brilliant blend of Zawinul's pioneering synthesizer work, Shorter's lyrical saxophone, and a powerful, funky rhythmic foundation.

pivotalTracks.title: Black Market
pivotalTracks.analysis: The title track is a perfect example of the band's evolving sound. It's built on an infectious, celebratory rhythm with a distinct Afro-pop feel. Joe Zawinul's pioneering use of the ARP 2600 synthesizer creates rich, orchestral textures that sounded like nothing else at the time. The track's joyous, accessible groove and sophisticated arrangement made it a standout and a key step towards the massive crossover success the band would achieve with their next album.

albums.label: Philly Jazz
albums.lineup: Sun Ra (organ, electric piano, synthesizer), John Gilmore (tenor saxophone), Marshall Allen (alto saxophone, flute), and other members of the Arkestra.
albums.description: A unique and surprisingly accessible album in Sun Ra's vast and often challenging discography. 'Lanquidity' finds the Arkestra exploring a deeply funky, atmospheric, and almost cinematic sound. The music is much more groove-oriented than his more avant-garde works, blending the hypnotic rhythms of funk and R&B with Sun Ra's signature spacey keyboard textures and soulful horn arrangements. It has become a cult classic and a favorite entry point into Sun Ra's unique musical universe.

tracklist.title: There Are Other Worlds (They Have Not Told You Of)

pivotalTracks.title: Lanquidity
pivotalTracks.analysis: The title track is a perfect example of the album's unique sound. It's a slow, hypnotic groove that has a noir-ish, almost detective-show feel. The relaxed, loping rhythm, combined with Sun Ra's spacey keyboard textures and the soulful horn lines, creates a sound that is both mysterious and infectious. It's a key example of Sun Ra's ability to absorb and transform popular music forms into his own cosmic vision.

albums.label: Tzadik
albums.lineup: John Zorn (alto saxophone), Marc Ribot (guitar), Jamie Saft (keyboards), Ikue Mori (electronics), Trevor Dunn (bass), Cyro Baptista (percussion), Kenny Wollesen (drums), Joey Baron (drums)
albums.description: A monumental live document, this album unleashes John Zorn's Masada songbook with the force of a rock band and the unbound chaos of free improvisation. The music is a thrilling, high-voltage extension of the fusion concept, blending traditional Jewish melodies with the raw power of noise rock and the avant-garde. The twin-drummer rhythm section provides a thunderous foundation for the searing solos of Zorn and guitarist Marc Ribot, creating a sound that is both sacred and profane.

pivotalTracks.title: Hath-Arob
pivotalTracks.analysis: This track perfectly captures the blistering energy of Electric Masada. The performance transforms a traditional-sounding Klezmer melody into an onslaught of sound, driven by dual drummers and the searing, distorted guitar of Marc Ribot. Zorn's own alto solo is a fiery, high-speed deconstruction of the theme. The music is a thrilling and essential document of the downtown New York scene, a powerful fusion of cultural heritage and avant-garde intensity.

albums.label: Young
albums.lineup: Kamasi Washington (tenor saxophone), Terrace Martin (alto saxophone), Patrice Quinn (vocals), Brandon Coleman (keyboards), Thundercat (bass), Ronald Bruner Jr. (drums), and guest artists.
albums.description: Described by Kamasi Washington as his 'dance album,' 'Fearless Movement' sees the spiritual jazz titan infusing his epic, cinematic sound with a new focus on funk, hip-hop, and danceable rhythms. The album is a powerful modern synthesis of the jazz tradition, blending the spiritual intensity of John Coltrane and the deep grooves of Parliament-Funkadelic. It features a host of guest artists, including George Clinton and André 3000, and stands as a vibrant and joyous celebration of movement and sound.

pivotalTracks.title: Prologue
pivotalTracks.analysis: A cover of a song by the legendary Detroit techno group Underground Resistance, this track is a powerful statement of the album's mission to connect jazz to the dance floor. The performance transforms the electronic original into a powerful, acoustic spiritual jazz anthem, driven by a thunderous, polyrhythmic drum beat and a soaring horn melody. It's a perfect example of how Washington continues to evolve by absorbing the sounds of different genres into his grand, cosmic vision.

albums.label: Impulse!
albums.lineup: Alice Coltrane (piano, harp), Pharoah Sanders (tenor saxophone, alto flute), Joe Henderson (tenor saxophone, alto flute), Ron Carter (bass), Ben Riley (drums)
albums.description: On this landmark album, her first after the passing of her husband John Coltrane, Alice Coltrane fully emerges as a major bandleader and composer. The music is a powerful and soulful blend of post-bop and the burgeoning spiritual jazz movement. Featuring the titanic saxophone pairing of Pharoah Sanders and Joe Henderson, the album is a key document of the era, bridging the gap between fiery, searching improvisation and a more cosmic, meditative sound.

pivotalTracks.title: Ptah, the El Daoud
pivotalTracks.analysis: The title track is a powerful modal piece that showcases the incredible saxophone frontline of Pharoah Sanders and Joe Henderson. The two tenors engage in a fiery, cathartic dialogue, their contrasting styles pushing each other to greater heights. Alice Coltrane's own piano playing is both percussive and profound, providing a powerful rhythmic and harmonic foundation. The track is a foundational text of spiritual jazz and a stunning artistic statement.

albums.label: Impulse!
albums.lineup: Alice Coltrane (harp, organ), Jimmy Garrison (bass), Jack DeJohnette (drums), Clifford Jarvis (drums), and a string orchestra arranged by Ornette Coleman.
albums.description: A groundbreaking work of spiritual and orchestral jazz, 'Universal Consciousness' is a cosmic symphony. Alice Coltrane combines her visionary organ and harp playing with a lush string section (with arrangements by Ornette Coleman), creating a sound that is both deeply devotional and avant-garde. The album is a swirling vortex of sound, blending jazz improvisation with complex orchestration to create a truly unique and otherworldly soundscape. It was a major step in expanding the sonic and spiritual possibilities of jazz.

pivotalTracks.title: Universal Consciousness
pivotalTracks.analysis: The title track is a revolutionary piece of music. Alice Coltrane's swirling, cosmic organ is the central voice, creating waves of sound that are both powerful and meditative. The string arrangements by Ornette Coleman add a layer of avant-garde classical texture, while the rhythm section of Jimmy Garrison and Jack DeJohnette provides a free, churning pulse. The result is a sound that transcends genre, a key document of both spiritual jazz and the 'Third Stream' movement.

albums.label: Milestone
albums.lineup: McCoy Tyner (piano, koto, flute, percussion), Sonny Fortune (alto saxophone, soprano saxophone, flute), Calvin Hill (bass), Alphonse Mouzon (drums)
albums.description: A powerful and influential album, 'Sahara' was a definitive statement from McCoy Tyner in his post-Coltrane career. The album is a brilliant showcase of his thunderous, modal piano style, and it incorporates African and Asian influences, with Tyner playing koto and flute in addition to piano. The music is a quintessential example of the powerful, Afro-centric, and spiritually charged jazz of the early 1970s, and it earned Tyner a Grammy nomination.

pivotalTracks.title: Ebony Queen
pivotalTracks.analysis: The album's opening track is a high-energy piece that perfectly captures the power and spirit of this quartet. It's a modal workout that features a fiery, searching soprano saxophone solo from Sonny Fortune and an absolutely explosive drum performance from Alphonse Mouzon. At the center of it all is Tyner's piano, a percussive force of nature that drives the band with its powerful left-hand rhythms and soaring right-hand lines. It's a classic performance of early 70s spiritual jazz.

albums.label: Milestone
albums.lineup: Joe Henderson (tenor saxophone), Alice Coltrane (piano, harp), Charlie Haden (bass), Leon 'Ndugu' Chancler (drums), Kenneth Nash (percussion)
albums.description: A landmark collaboration, this album brings together a supergroup of spiritually-inclined jazz masters for a four-part suite based on the classical elements. The music is a deep, meditative, and expansive journey, blending Joe Henderson's powerful, searching tenor saxophone with the cosmic sound of Alice Coltrane's piano and harp. The album is a high-water mark of spiritual jazz, a powerful and unique statement that stands apart in the discographies of all involved.

pivotalTracks.title: Fire
pivotalTracks.analysis: The opening movement of the suite, 'Fire,' is a powerful and intense performance. Joe Henderson's tenor saxophone playing is fiery and exploratory, a perfect match for the track's theme. Alice Coltrane's piano provides a powerful, modal foundation, while the rhythm section creates a churning, polyrhythmic pulse. The track is a brilliant example of how the spiritual jazz movement could be both meditative and intensely energetic.

albums.label: Impulse!
albums.lineup: Pharoah Sanders (tenor saxophone), Joe Bonner (piano), Cecil McBee (bass), Norman Connors (drums), James Mtume (percussion), Badal Roy (percussion)
albums.description: This live album perfectly captures the two sides of Pharoah Sanders's musical personality: the fiery, avant-garde explorer and the soulful, spiritual guru. The album features two side-long tracks, one a joyous, accessible vocal chant ('Love Is Everywhere') and the other a deep, intense, and exploratory instrumental. It's a key document of Sanders's live show in the mid-70s, showcasing his ability to connect with an audience on both a spiritual and a visceral level.

pivotalTracks.title: Love Is Everywhere
pivotalTracks.analysis: A classic Pharoah Sanders live performance, 'Love Is Everywhere' is a joyous, uplifting piece built around a simple, infectious vocal chant. The track's gospel-infused groove creates a feeling of pure celebration and community with the audience. Over this foundation, Sanders delivers one of his signature, fiery tenor solos, a cathartic and spiritual cry. It's a key example of how he could blend intense, free-form improvisation with a deeply soulful and accessible core.

albums.albumTitle: Prepare Thyself to Deal With a Miracle
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.lineup: Rahsaan Roland Kirk (tenor saxophone, flute, various instruments), Charles McGhee (trumpet), Dick Griffin (trombone), Harry Smiles (oboe), and a large ensemble.
albums.description: One of Rahsaan Roland Kirk's most experimental and deeply personal albums. 'Prepare Thyself' is a key example of his 'black classical music,' blending large ensemble orchestration with sound collages, nature recordings, and Kirk's own transcendent multi-instrumental abilities. The music is a sprawling, spiritual journey that defies easy categorization, showcasing a unique artist at his most visionary and uncompromising. It's a deep dive into the mind of a true original.

pivotalTracks.title: Salvation and Reminiscing
pivotalTracks.analysis: This track is a perfect example of the album's unique and ambitious sound. It blends a soulful, gospel-inflected theme with sections of avant-garde orchestration, sound effects, and Kirk's own passionate, multi-layered improvisations. The piece moves seamlessly between moments of sublime beauty and chaotic intensity, creating a powerful and deeply personal spiritual narrative. It's Kirk at his most compositional and visionary.

albums.label: Milestone
albums.lineup: McCoy Tyner (piano), Azar Lawrence (tenor saxophone, soprano saxophone), Joony Booth (bass), Alphonse Mouzon (drums)
albums.description: Recorded live at the Montreux Jazz Festival, this album captures the immense power and spiritual intensity of McCoy Tyner's mid-70s quartet. The music is a torrent of energy, driven by Tyner's thunderous piano and the explosive drumming of Alphonse Mouzon. The album is a quintessential example of live spiritual jazz at its most potent, with the band taking the modal concepts Tyner pioneered with Coltrane to a new level of intensity.

pivotalTracks.title: Walk Spirit, Talk Spirit
pivotalTracks.analysis: This sprawling, 24-minute performance is a tour de force of live, high-energy spiritual jazz. The piece is a modal workout that serves as a launching pad for soaring, transcendent solos from Tyner and saxophonist Azar Lawrence. The rhythm section of Booth and Mouzon is a powerhouse, creating a relentless, churning pulse. The track perfectly captures the cathartic, almost overwhelming energy of Tyner's live performances during this period.

albums.label: Black Saint
albums.lineup: Billy Harper (tenor saxophone), Virgil Jones (trumpet), Joe Bonner (piano), David Friesen (bass), Malcolm Pinson (drums)
albums.description: The inaugural release on the legendary Italian label of the same name, this powerful album is a key document of 1970s spiritual jazz. Tenor saxophonist Billy Harper leads a brilliant quintet through a set of powerful, modal compositions that are both politically charged and deeply spiritual. Harper's tenor sound is immense and declarative, a spiritual cry rooted in the language of John Coltrane. The album is a masterpiece of the genre and a definitive statement from a major voice.

tracklist.title: Call of the Wild and Peaceful Heart

pivotalTracks.title: Croquet Ballet
pivotalTracks.analysis: This track is a perfect example of Billy Harper's powerful and sophisticated compositional style. The piece has a majestic, hymn-like quality, but it's also a vehicle for intense and fiery improvisation. Harper's own solo is a tour de force, a powerful sermon delivered through his tenor saxophone. The performance is a key example of how the spiritual jazz movement blended complex, post-bop harmony with the emotional directness of the church.

albums.label: Mustevic Sound
albums.lineup: Steve Reid (drums), Joe Rigby (saxophones), Iqua Colson (vocals), Richard Williams (bass), David Wertman (bass)
albums.description: A key document of the 1970s loft jazz scene, 'Nova' is a raw and powerful piece of independent, Afro-centric free jazz. The music is centered on the explosive, polyrhythmic drumming of leader Steve Reid, who had played with everyone from James Brown to Sun Ra. The album is a journey of pure energy, driven by Reid's propulsive rhythms and featuring fiery saxophone work and soaring, wordless vocals. It's a vital example of the spiritual and revolutionary music being made outside the mainstream record industry.

pivotalTracks.title: Nova
pivotalTracks.analysis: The title track is a powerful and hypnotic piece of spiritual free jazz. The music is built on a foundation of Reid's powerful, polyrhythmic drumming and a churning two-bass groove. Over this, Joe Rigby's saxophone is a searing, free-form cry, while Iqua Colson's wordless vocals add a unique, ethereal texture. The track is a perfect example of the raw, uncompromising, and deeply spiritual music that was flourishing in the New York loft scene of the 1970s.

albums.label: A&M
albums.lineup: Don Cherry (trumpet, vocals), Frank Lowe (tenor saxophone), Ricky Cherry (piano), Stanley Clarke (bass), Billy Higgins (drums), and others.
albums.description: This album features the track 'Brown Rice,' a landmark of world fusion and spiritual jazz. The album finds the free jazz pioneer exploring a more accessible, groove-oriented sound, blending funk, rock, and his signature global influences. The music is a joyous and eclectic mix, showcasing Cherry's vision of a truly universal music that transcended genres and borders. It remains one of his most beloved and influential recordings.

pivotalTracks.title: Brown Rice
pivotalTracks.analysis: A classic track and a cornerstone of world fusion, 'Brown Rice' is an infectious and hypnotic groove. Don Cherry blends a funky, electric bass-driven rhythm with influences from Indian and African music, his own pocket trumpet weaving melodic fragments throughout. The track's mantra-like vocals and eclectic instrumentation created a unique, accessible sound that was both deeply spiritual and irresistibly danceable, influencing a generation of artists inside and outside of jazz.

albums.genres: Spiritual Jazz, Third Stream, Avant-Garde Jazz
albums.label: Impulse!
albums.lineup: Alice Coltrane (harp, organ), Jimmy Garrison (bass), Jack DeJohnette (drums), Clifford Jarvis (drums), Rashied Ali (drums), and a string orchestra arranged by Ornette Coleman.
albums.description: A groundbreaking work of spiritual and orchestral jazz, 'Universal Consciousness' is a cosmic symphony. Alice Coltrane combines her visionary organ and harp playing with a lush string section (with arrangements co-written by Ornette Coleman), creating a sound that is both deeply devotional and avant-garde. The album is a swirling vortex of sound, blending jazz improvisation with complex orchestration to create a truly unique and otherworldly soundscape. It was a major step in expanding the sonic and spiritual possibilities of jazz.

The result is a sound that transcends genre, a key document of both spiritual jazz and the 'Third Stream' movement.

albums.label: Milestone
albums.lineup: Joe Henderson (tenor saxophone), Alice Coltrane (piano, harp, harmonium, tambura), Charlie Haden (bass), Leon 'Ndugu' Chancler (drums), Kenneth Nash (percussion)
albums.description: A landmark collaboration, this album brings together a supergroup of spiritually-inclined jazz masters for a four-part suite based on the classical elements. The music is a deep, meditative, and expansive journey, blending Joe Henderson's powerful, searching tenor saxophone with the cosmic sound of Alice Coltrane's piano and harp. The album is a high-water mark of spiritual jazz, a powerful and unique statement that stands apart in the discographies of all involved.

pivotalTracks.title: Earth
pivotalTracks.analysis: The final movement of the suite, 'Earth,' is a deep and hypnotic groove. The track is built on an infectious, repeated bass line from Charlie Haden, creating a powerful, earthy foundation. Over this, Henderson's tenor saxophone and Coltrane's piano engage in a searching, spiritual dialogue. The track is a perfect example of the album's unique chemistry and its ability to create music that is both grounded and transcendent.

albums.label: Impulse!
albums.lineup: Pharoah Sanders (tenor saxophone), Joe Bonner (piano), Cecil McBee (bass), Norman Connors (drums), James Mtume (percussion), Badal Roy (percussion), Lawrence Killian (congas)
albums.description: This live album perfectly captures the two sides of Pharoah Sanders's musical personality: the fiery, avant-garde explorer and the soulful, spiritual guru. The album features two side-long tracks, one a joyous, accessible vocal chant ('Love Is Everywhere') and the other a deep, intense, and exploratory instrumental dedicated to John Coltrane. It's a key document of Sanders's live show in the mid-70s, showcasing his ability to connect with an audience on both a spiritual and a visceral level.

It's a key example of how he could blend intense, free-form improvisation with a deeply soulful and accessible core.
